WRITING.TEXT: Don't forget your camera's crop factor
Jfigg
What it's like when the beat is about to drop.

I explained this to other guy, and since you asked similar question I'll copy paste.
**Light Frames** Are the images that contains the real information: images of galaxies, nebula... This is what you want to stack.
**Dark frames** Removes dark signal from your image (stuff you don't want to see) it's easy to take dark frames. After you take your light frames (the object you were photographing) put the lens cap on the lens and shoot between 15 or 100 images with the same settings, don't change nothing, don't move your setup, shoot in the same place right after your light frames, because temperature is important for dark frames.
**Bias/Offset frames** I'm not sure if they really improve the quality of the final image that much, but they also remove some stuff that shouldn't be there, also you don't have to take them after each set, you can take them once and use them for half a year or so, of course the ISO is important for those frames and let's say if you take light frames with 1600 ISO one day and you only have Bias frames that are 800 ISO, you then have to create library for Bias frames, if you are changing the ISO frequently you should have Bias frame library that you can choose from to match the ISO of your light frames. To take Bias frames is very easy, temperature is not important, put the lens cap on, change your shutter speed to fastest possible (1/4000s, 1/8000s) and shoot between 15 and 100 of them.
**Flat frames** I'm a beginner too so I haven't figured out the proper way how to take flats, but from what I read is that you drape a clean white t-shirt over your lens and shine a flashlight perpendicular to the lens, of course not too close to the lens, and you take also between 15 and 100 of them. The flat frames should be created with the ISO speed of the light frames. The temperature is not important, and shoot in Av mode.
P.S. If you have taken 20 light frames and you then take 100 dark frames that doesn't make sense so, take less of those frames than your lights. Of course if you take 500 lights you can take 200-400 darks if you have time ;)
I curious how fast they were going?
I can shake my eyeballs fast.

It is possible with the 200mm you just have to take a lot of images of the object and then stack them in Deep sky stacker, remember the rule of 500 (500/your focal length = maximum exposure of your image without visible star trails) also keep in mind your camera's crop factor, for my camera it's 1.6x so it would be 500/(2001.6) And if you want better image quality you also need to take dark, flat and bias frames. If you have questions please ask. Edit: if you want longer exposures of your images you can try increasing the rule to maybe 550 or 600
I'd like to know what it is as well.
How did you achieve 4 point stars?

It's not important at all to maintain the alignment, you just have to keep what you want to see in frame, for example deep sky object moves a bit after several shots, I adjust the angle of the camera a bit, take more shots, adjust again, so it's not important at all, the deep sky stacker will automatically align and stack your images. Of course if you have a stationary foreground in your image (city, mountains, some landscape) the deep sky stacker will mess it up, and you have to manually take that foreground shot and later add it to your post processed sky image. And my advice is to not process the image in the DSS after it has been stacked, when it's done stacking just save the image to .tif integer 32-bit and you're good to go to other processing programs (I usually first go to Photoshop and then later to lightroom). Hope that helps. If you have more questions please ask.

Canon 70D + Tamron 70-300mm @ 300mm + 1.6x crop factor = 480mm + tripod 300x1s lights @ f5.6 ISO 3200 (5min) 100x1s darks @ f5.6 ISO 3200 95x1/8000s Offset/Bias
Stacked with DSS, Processed with photoshop and lightroom (levels, curves, histogram, color balance, vibrance, saturation, highlights, shadows, etc..)
[TIF Link](https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B9y8ylhe9rpoNXh5ZFIxYnRkZ00/view?usp=sharing) I would love to see how other people would process my image differently and what results they'd achieve, if you are willing to help me improve my post processing, please describe briefly what steps you went through processing the image. Thank you.

WRITING.TITLE: First attempt at M45 Pleiades, your processed image is more than welcome

WRITING.TEXT: I'm new to astrophotography too, but I think your exposure time is a little bit too long, generally you want to have rule of 500 in mind (500/focal length=longest exposure of your image without experiencing star trails) also keep in mind your camera's crop factor, if it has one, my example is I often shoot at 300mm and my camera crop factor is 1.6x so that's 480mm focal length 500/480= roughly 1s maximum of exposure for single image.

I'm really curious about those star trails at 1s exposure. I may have an idea what may cause it. I found an article that says IS may cause moving objects to blur, here's an extract: Before getting into the nitty-gritty of the subject, its important to clarify a common misconception about image stabilization, which is that it enables you to freeze fast-moving objects at slower shutter speeds. This is totally false. Image stabilization only allows you the ability to capture sharp images of static subjects at slower speeds. Moving objects will be equally blurry or streakyand in some casesblurrier or shakierwith the IS turned on.
And the other idea would be to weigh down some weight on the tripod hook. So yeah, learning every day.

WRITING.TITLE: That's it I'm done with this show
WRITING.TEXT:
With each episode this show has gone more and more stupid, the characters are the most annoying part of the show, Carol the most annoying stupid little fucker in this show, I waited so many episodes for someone to shut her ass up and she kept getting more crazy, Tandy the most pretentious annoying idiot who can't be himself, it's like he follows the stupidity from Carol, always trying to be more disturbing to everyone, Melissa, arrogant, ignorant, contributes no value to the show, the other characters are only passive to the show. The only character that has any value and is somewhat reasonable and interesting is Todd, honest, genuine person.
I don't really understand what people love about this show, it continuosly gets more and more frustrating to watch, the characters are dumb as f*ck and it gets worse and worse with every episode. I only started to watch this show because how interesting and good the first few episodes were, then it somehow progressively got boring and predictable...
I really feel like I'm the only person in this sub who sees this show the way it is and I hope I'm not the only one in the world who sees it such way...
The downvotes are fine, as long as I express my opinion on the internet.
Bye bye show, On to the next one.
Edit: **Haha so butthurt for a mediocre show..**

There's an after life, it's just difficult for people who live their lives based on what scientists know about us and our universe to understand that there might be some other place, some other dimension or spirutual existence that hasn't been discovered or observed. If there's no evidence for something, that doesn't mean you have to immediately disprove it, sometimes you just have to believe it no matter when most of the society is telling you not to because the scientists don't know about it. What do you loose by believing something unearthly, nothing, and you dont know what you might loose when you die, so believing in higher power costs you nothing.
I'm okay with downvotes, it's all good as long as I share my opinion on the internet. People will eventually start to think differently about God and after life in the near future as we will start to discover and study our spiritual sides.

WRITING.TITLE: I am completely new in the console world.
WRITING.TEXT:
I never had a console, never really played on a console, well maybe few times, I've always been the PC guy, I always played games on the mid-end PC. The reason I've never been in to consoles is because I've never had the money to buy it, or if I had, there were more important things for me to buy. And now the time has come for me to finally buy the frickin' console and I decided to go with PS4, but now I'm considering about the games, should I buy discs or digital? One reason I don't want to buy discs is because I would have to insert them every time I want to play a game, on the other hand what I heard about the digital version is that some accounts are getting banned for no reason, so I'm kind of stuck between two options. Can you help me decide?
**Edit:** It is done, I just bought PS4 Ultimate Player 1TB edition and couple of games (GTA V and NBA 2K16) (physical)
A few more questions came in to mind. **1.** Will I be able to store my videos, music in PS4 hard drive? **2.** Can PS4 play 4K videos?
